newsitem.title: SENEGAL: Senegal holds re-runs after chaotic local polls.
newsitem.headline: Senegal holds re-runs after chaotic local polls.

text.p: Senegal re-ran its local elections in 100 polling centres in the capital Dakar on Wednesday after organisational chaos prevented many people from voting, particularly in the suburbs.
The main opposition Senegalese Democratic Party (PDS), which has called for the results nationwide of Sunday's poll to be scrapped, nevertheless took part in the re-runs.
Polls opened on time at 8 a.m. (0800 GMT) after the army ensured that voting materials were in the right place on Tuesday evening. They were due to close at 6 p.m.
Results from other areas have yet to be formally declared.
PDS leader Abdoulaye Wade, defeated by President Abdou Diouf in disputed presidential elections in 1993, was running for the job of mayor of the capital Dakar.
The ruling Socialist Party was trying on Sunday to recapture the urban vote which it lost to the opposition during presidential and parliamentary polls in 1993.
The opposition boycotted the last municipal polls which took place in 1989 before Senegal's transition to more open multi-party politics.
Fourteen political parties were contesting seats on regional, municipal, district and rural councils on Sunday. Just over three million people were eligible to vote then.
